turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: If one of you can get that  -- I mean, I want the real Superman. Who is he? Where's he from? What's his favorite ball team? What's up?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: He is. Usually.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Whoever comes up with that will make Woodward and Bernstein look like Abbot and Costello.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Easy now, miss, I've got you???

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: You've got me? Who's got you???

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Do as I say. Let go!

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Oh, God! I'm going to die!

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Not while I'm around you're not. C'mon...

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Who...who...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Let's just say I'm a friend.  And watch yourself from now on with those things, Okay?  I mean if the good lord wanted people to fly he would have given them wings.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: With my luck, now it'll rain.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Not a chance. It's too nice a night.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Superman???

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Right on the first guess.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Wha'...what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I came to talk to you.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: The answer is yes. Now what's the question?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: There's been a lot of confusion in the media about who I am and what I'm up to and all that. I'd like to set the record straight. With your help.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: This is incredible. I was just sitting here trying to figure out how to contact you. I mean, you don't have an answering service, right?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Unlisted number, Shall we proceed?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Well...flashlight?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I think you'll be able to remember it. I doubt you'll misquote me.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: If I do, you can punish  me. Fly me to Bermuda and just lave me there for two weeks.  This is fantastic! I wish Clark were here.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Who's Clark? One of your colleagues?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Not exactly. He's kind of a rewrite man. Actually, he's a bit dull, if you know what I mean.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Oh, I've got to get some matches.  My cigarette.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I'd appreciate it if you didn't smoke.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Oh.  Well, where do we start?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Ask, You're the girl reporter.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Okay. Let's start with these strange powers of yours.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: You think they're strange?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: I didn't mean that in any pejorative way.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I guess they are a little odd.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Well, I mean it's not everybody that can deliver an air mail letter without putting a stamp on it.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I wouldn't do that. It's against the law.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: The reason I can fly is because my molecular structure is so constituted that I have a lighter density under Earth's gravitational force.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: It must feel great.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: It's not bad.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Thirty-five.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: How much do you weigh?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: 195 pounds.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: What about this X-Ray vision of yours?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Can you really see through anything?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Is it true you're impervious to pain?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Yes. Although I can get a headache just like anyone.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Do bullets really bounce off you?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Only when somebody shoots them at me.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: What color underwear am I wearing?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Pink.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Can you actually fly faster than the speed of sound?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Do you like pink?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Very much.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Where do you hail from?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Well, I was born on a planet your scientists don't know too much about. It's in the Xeno Galaxy. Or it was. It was called Krypton. That's K-R-Y-P...

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: No speeches, Otis. Just watch what Albert has prepared.  What are you waiting for?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Now then, Otis. Did you get what I asked for?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Yessir. Just what you wanted.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: There.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Not there!  A pine tree in Death Valley? Idiot! This is for the North Woods section!

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Did I do good, Mr. Luthor?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Excellent, Otis.  But what took you so long?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: What's the matter, Otis?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Matter? With me? Nothing's the matter.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Otis, were you up to your old tricks?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: I broke the man out of prison --

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I'll always be grateful, Mr. Luthor.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: I gave him steady employment --

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I'll never forget you for that, Mr. Luthor.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: I gave him this new face.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I...uh...check.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: And now he lies to me. He has been stealing ladies' purses again.  Haven't you? Haven't you, you miserable petty crook?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I guess I...uh...regressed.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Please...

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Otis...

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Is that real enough for you?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: It is for me.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Y'know? I'm sure of it. Y'know? And there's a strong streak of goody- goody in him that is going to blow this deal for me if I don't do something about it.  Something!

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: But, to someone from the planet Krypton, this substance would be lethal because of its high level of radioactivity. Kryptonite! Ah, Kryptonite! That's the stuff!

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: You mean bullets and fire and all that can't hurt him, but this kind of rock --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Will kill him! And I'm going to have a piece of the rock! Miss Teschmacher, pack your --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Well, gents? What did I tell you? It's a piece of cake.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: It's a Twinkie, boss.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: They're killing me by inches!  Go ahead! Make me suffer! Milk me dry.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Maybe it's being polished or something. Maybe they're cleaning it.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Cleaning a rock, Otis?  Jot it down. As soon as we're back, he feeds the pets.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Luthor...

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I still don't get it.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Ah, dear simple Otis. Albert explain it to him.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Sort of.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Good enough for you. Now then --  --  tell me something I like to hear. As many times as I hear it...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: What is this??!

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Makes Cecil B. DeMille look like the Senior Class play, right?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: But...why?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Well  --  you've got me! What can I say?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Plenty! About 'The Crime of the Century,' Remember?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Oh, that. Listen  --  you're busy  --  and it's a long story --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: This is California. The richest, most populous state in America. And growing like a sonofagun.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I don't need a geography lesson, Luthor.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: No, Superman, of course not. You do get around, don't you.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: It's just that  --  I spent a fortune on these things!  And all for naught! What a waste  --

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Of time, Luthor.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Right, right. Where was I? Ah, yes --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: At the San Andreas Fault. Maybe you've heard of it.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Sure. It's the joining together of two land masses pushed together eight million years ago. The fault line itself is unstable and always shifting, which is the reason you get earthquakes in the California area from time to time.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Couldn't have said it better myself.  Now all this  --  --  west of the Fault is the most expensive real estate in the world. Los Angeles. San Diego. San Francisco. And here  --  --  is just hundreds and hundreds of miles of cheap desert land. Land that happens to be owned by Lex Luthor Enterprises. Well...  ...call me a fool, but ...it did occur to me that if a conventional five hundred megaton bomb were to explode at exactly the proper stress point --  --  that would trigger the upheaval that would cause the San Andreas Fault to 'do its thing.'  Ah, it would've been so nice, y'know...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Nice! Most of California would have been destroyed. Millions of people would've been killed! The West Coast as we know it would have  --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: --  Dropped into the sea!  Bye-bye California! Hello, new West Coast! Gold Coast! My Coast.  And now...well...  I left my heart in San Francisco...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: It would never have worked, Luthor. You are a dreamer  --  a sick, twisted dreamer.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Maybe I should get help.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: It wouldn't hurt. You can't go on living in fantasies. Did you really think you could get hold of a nuclear bomb? And drop it?  Why, our Strategic Defense boys would have  --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: You're right, you're right, Superman. There were wrinkles to iron out. But, well...  ...there is this new rocket, the XK 101.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: The XK 101. Luthor, that operates on radio waves. And with our fail-safe system, only the President himself can push that button.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: I know. I know.  I never promised myself a rose garden.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Still, foolishly, perhaps, I had a theory that eliminates the Presidential push-button.  I was doing my homework...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: On radio waves?

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: And garbage doors.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Luthor  --

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: You guessed it!  You're always one step ahead of me.  Aren't you Superman?  Yes, right. There was a police helicopter buzzing the area and transmitting on the same frequency as the garage doors. The minute the signal went out --  Zip!  Zip!  Zip!

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Well, that's their problem, T.S. But  --  but the XK 101 also works on a radio wave control system. The problem was to find out the frequency. Problems, problems, I've had so many...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: They'll soon be over.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: In a way  -- oh, it'll be a relief. I'm a wreck. No rest for the wicked, y'know. It wasn't enough, the radio frequencies, then I had to worry about getting to the missile and adjusting the aiming. So that if I could have activated the launch  -- well, Lex Luthor would've hit the spot.  There's a little place on Route 190. Dead on the practice optimum stress point of the San Andreas Fault. It wouldn't mean much to you, Superman, but I call it...target zero.  Pancho's Taco Palace...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Well, it's very impressive but you built this junk for nothing.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: For the first time today, Superman I must tell you that you're wrong.  But how could you know that -  Oh, well. I guess I could tell you now. Y'see, actually...but this conversation is becoming rather dry, isn't it.

turns.speaker: LUTHOR
turns.text: Now who's the dreamer, Superman? Even you can't fly that fast!

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: We'll see how fast I can fly.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Yes, we do know each other.  I'm Alison Jones.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Alison Jones.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Ally.  That was my nickname.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Ally.  That's right.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: How are you?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm just fine, Ally.  What about you?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: I'm fine.  Still working with my father.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: And what does he do again?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: He used to work with you.  Until you found out he was having an affair with your wife.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Ally Jones.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: How is Mrs. Stephens?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: We're...not together.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: I'd heard that.  But she's well?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes...fine.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: And Zoe?  How's Zoe?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: I'm glad to hear that Zoe's okay.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Are you still in touch?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Not really.  The last time I saw her was at that clinic.  That was a long time ago.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Which one?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Which one?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Which clinic?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: I don't remember the name.  It was near a beach.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Sunnyridge.  That was a long time

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: So there were others?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Other clinics?  Oh sure.  Clinics, half-way houses, treatment centers, detox units...

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Then...when did she get better?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: She didn't.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: But you said...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's where I'm going.  To see her.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: She's in trouble?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.  Do you find there's something strange about this meat?

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: What...does it turn to?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It turns to steaming piss.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm...so sorry.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: That's okay.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: I...don't think so.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I woke to the sound of Zoe's breathing.  It was laboured.  I looked over and noticed she was sweating and all swollen.  I grabbed her, rushed to the kitchen, and splashed water on her face.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I didn't know.  I was in a panic.  I guessed she'd been bitten by an insect, but there was no doctor. The nearest hospital was forty miles away, and Zoe was continuing to swell.  Klara took her in her arms and tried to breast-feed her, while I dialed the hospital.  I finally got a doctor on the line.  He sounded young, but cool.  He was confident, but there was a nervousness.  He have been an intern.  This was the first time he ever had to deal with anything like this.  He wanted to seem like he knew what he was doing, but he was just as scared as I was.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Nothing.  We made it to the hospital.  I didn't have to go as far as I was prepared to.  But I was prepared to go all the way.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Well, it was nice meeting you again, Mr. Stephens.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Mitchell.  It was nice to see you again, Ally.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Alison.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Alison.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: Say hi to Zoe.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: ALISON
turns.text: I hope she gets better.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'll tell her that.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: My name is...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Mister, I don't want to know your name.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: No you don't.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I can help you.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Not unless you can raise the dead.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Mr. Mitchell Stephens, Esquire, would you be likely to sue me if I was to beat you right now?  Beat you so bad that you pissed blood and couldn't walk for a month.  Because that's what I'm about to do.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: No, Mr. Ansel.  I wouldn't sue you.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Leave us alone, Stephens.  Leave the people of this town alone.  You can't help.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You can help each other.  Several people have agreed to let me represent them in a negligence suit. Your case as an individual will be stronger if I'm allowed to represent you together as a group.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Case?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: The Walkers have agreed.  The Ottos. Nicole Burnell's parents.  It's important to initiate proceedings right away.  Things get covered up. People lie.  That's why we have to begin our investigation quickly. Before the evidence disappears. That's why I'm out here tonight.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I know Risa and Wendell Walker. They wouldn't hire a goddamned lawyer.  And the Ottos wouldn't deal

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's my daughter.  Or it may be the police to tell me that they've found her dead.  She's a drug addict.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why are you telling me this?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm telling you this because... we've all lost our children, Mr. Ansel.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's my daughter.  Or it may be the police to tell me that they've found her dead.  She's a drug addict.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why are you telling me this?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm telling you this because we've all lost our children, Mr. Ansel...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Hi, Nicole.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Hi, Mr. Ansel.  Hi, Jessica, Mason...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: They just finished supper.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Was it good?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'll be back around nine.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: It just seems...kind of weird.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Nicole, I'm just going to pack all this stuff and give it to the church for charity.  Don't feel bad. Unless you feel strange about wearing it.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.  I mean, I remember Mrs. Ansel wearing some of this stuff, but...I don't feel funny about that.  I really liked her.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: And she really liked you.  She would've given you all this if she'd outgrown it, or...

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: What do you mean 'outgrown it'?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Oh.  Right.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Goodnight, Mr. Ansel.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Goodnight, Nicole.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why would he do that?  You didn't have anything to do with the accident.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Because I was driving behind the bus, Mary.  Because I saw it.  I saw it happen...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I used to like it here.  I used to care about what happened.  Now I think I'll sell my house and move the fuck away.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Billy, please.  The children.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: The children.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: How is Nicole?  Is she around?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She's resting.  In her room.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Say hello for me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So what brings you out tonight?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Well, Sam, I might as well tell you the truth.  It's this lawsuit you've gotten yourself all involved with. I want you to drop the damned thing.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't see how that concerns you, Billy.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: It does concern me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, I don't know why it should. There's a whole lot of people in town involved with lawsuits.  We're hardly unique here, Billy.  I mean, I can understand how you feel.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, it being so depressing and all.  But it's reality.  You can't just turn this off because you happen to think it's a bad idea.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Because it's what we have to do.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Well I don't want a damned thing to do with it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Okay, fine.  So...stay out of it.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I've tried to stay out of it.  But it turns out that's not so easy, Sam.  You've gone and got yourself this lawyer.  Mitchell Stephens. You and Risa and Wendell and the Ottos.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So?  I mean, lot's of folks have got lawyers.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: But yours is the one who's going to subpoena me, Sam.  Force me to testify in court.  He came by the garage this afternoon.  Gave me this piece of paper.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: If that bastard does subpoena me, if he forces me to go over this again, then all those other lawyers will line up behind him and try and do the same thing.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That won't happen, Billy.  Mitch Stephens' case is small, compared to some of those other guys.  The way he told me, all he needs is for you to say what you saw that day, driving behind the bus.  I know it's a painful thing to do, but it'll only take a few minutes of your time.  That'll be the end of it.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: That's wrong, Sam.  You know that. We'll be tangled up in this thing for the next five years.  This is never going to go away...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: C'mon, you know that won't...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: We've got lawyers suing lawyers because some people were stupid enough to sign on with more than one of the bastards.  We've got people pointing fingers, making side deals, and dickering over percentages. Yesterday, I heard somebody wants to sue the rescue squad.  The rescue squad.  Because they didn't act fast enough.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No, Billy.  We can't drop the lawsuit.  You know how much we need the money.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why?  You got money from Dolores' insurance with the school board.  We all did.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It's not enough.  For hospital bills.  For Nicole.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'll help pay for Nicole, if that's what you're really talking about. I'll even give you the money I got for my kids.  That's what we used to do, remember? Help each other.  This was a community.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Nicole's coming over to look after the kids tonight.  She'll be there around six.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Billy, that's too early.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: She said she's got to be home by nine.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Can't you make it later?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Have you been waiting long?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: A while.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Billy, do you have to smoke? Wendell can smell if someone's been smoking.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Does this mean I can't take a shower?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: No.  It should be dry by now.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: What time's he coming home?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: When the game's over, I guess.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: What are you thinking?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Tomorrow I'm going to put Sean on the bus.  He won't want to go.  He never does.  He'll cry and want to hold on to me.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: That's because he misses you.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: It's natural.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Your kids never cry.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Well, maybe that's because they know I'm going to follow them.  Behind the bus.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: They can look forward to that.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Just like we look forward to this.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: You're leaving.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I better get back.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Good night, Billy.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I stopped by the station a while ago.  I stared at the bus.  I could almost hear the kids inside.  There was a lawyer there.  He told me he'd gotten you signed up.  Is that true?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Something made this happen, Billy. Mr. Stephens is going to find out what it was.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Mr. Stephens says that someone didn't put a right bolt in the bus...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Risa, I serviced that bus.  At the garage.  There's nothing wrong with it.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: ...or that the guardrail wasn't strong enough.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: You believe that?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: I have to.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Because I have to.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Well I don't.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Is it true that you gave Nicole one of Lydia's dresses?  That she was wearing it when the bus crashed?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: RISA
turns.text: Why did you do that, Billy?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: You think that caused the accident, Risa?  That it brought bad luck? Christ, it sounds to me you're looking for a witch doctor, not a lawyer.  Or maybe they're the same thing.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Dolores.  No one calls me 'Mrs. Driscoll'.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What do you mean by that, Dolores?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: About the Ottos?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.  What do you mean by 'hippies'?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: I mean, the way they look.  Their hair and clothing...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Do they have any reputation for drugs?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: No, nothing like that.  The Ottos are what I'd call model citizens. They're regular at town meetings. They give their opinions  in a respectful way.  They always help out at various fund-raising bazaars in town , though they aren't church goers.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: And they loved Bear.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Oh yes.  Like I said, they always came out together to see him off to school.  It's like he was their little treasure.  He was such a beautiful boy.  That's a picture of him on the wall there, behind Abbott.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Those are all from the fair last year.  Abbott and me were judges at the pet show.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: For rabbits?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Billy loved to see his kids in the bus.  They always sat in the back, so they could wave to each other. It comforted him.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: From what?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: From what?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Did he have any particular problems that you knew of?  Financial pressures...run-ins with the law...

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: No, nothing like that.  Billy's wife, Lydia, died of cancer a few years ago.  He took over raising the children by himself.  It was obvious how much he missed Lydia.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You talked about it?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: No.  I saw it on his face.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: That's the way I thought of them sometimes.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Berries.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Yes.  Like I was putting them into my big basket.  Clearing the hillside of its children.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Abbott and I used to do a lot of that in the spring.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Berry-picking.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Yes.  The old-fashioned way.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: And what's that?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: With our hands.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: A strange little fellow, but you couldn't help liking him.  He was close to ten but seemed more like a frightened five or six.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Were his parents...attentive to him?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You mentioned that he had a learning disability.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Did his parents attend to that?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Did they give him special care?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: The Walkers loved Sean.  He was their only child...the object of all their attention.  I mean, Wendell's a withdrawn sort of man.  That's his nature.  But Risa, she's still got dreams.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: I have a question for you, Mr. Stephens.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What's that, Dolores?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: I told you that I was doing fifty miles an hour when the accident happened.  That's how I remembered it.  But the truth is, I might have been doing sixty.  Or sixty five. And if that's true, that I was over the limit when the bus went over, what would happen then?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That would complicate things.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Because I'd be to blame, right?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Billy Ansel will insist that you were driving fifty-one miles an hour.  Just like you've done every morning for the past fifteen years.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: He knows that?  Billy?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.  He does.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Billy said that?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: You've talked to Billy?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: And Billy told you that he'll tell that to...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Mrs.  Driscoll, if Billy Ansel does not volunteer to say so in court, I will subpoena him and oblige him to testify to that effect.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It's clear to me and other people that you have suffered significantly from this event.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: What other people?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Who's been talking to you about what I'm feeling?  Who should care about what I'm feeling?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: You heard what Abbott said?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Anything you didn't understand?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: There might have been a word or two that slipped by.  Maybe you could clarify it for me, just to be absolutely sure.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's what he said, is it?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Yes.  Abbot understands these things.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: He never took his eyes off his mother, even as he moved to sit beside Nicole.  He looked frightened.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Why would he be frightened?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: I don't know.  But it was weird in terms of what happened next.  Sean was still watching his mother.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Good morning, Wanda.  Hi, Hartley.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Hi, Dolores.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Well, it's certainly what you'd call interesting.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: You hate it.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: I didn't say that.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: I could wrap it up.  Protect the other kids.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: I'll just strap it on the roof.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: It's for the school bazaar.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Oh, it's bizarre alright.  C'mon Bear.  Let's get you out of here.

turns.speaker: WANDA
turns.text: Away from your crazy Mom.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: The Ottos always waited for the bus with Bear.  They were the only parents who did that, together like that.  I guess they're what you might call hippies.

turns.speaker: HARTLEY
turns.text: You want a cup of tea or something?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: A cup of tea would be nice.  Would it be alright if I sit down for a few minutes, Mrs. Otto?  I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: HARTLEY
turns.text: But Dolores said she saw a dog and tried to...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: How long has Dolores been driving that bus, Mr. Otto?  How many times has she steered clear of danger? What went wrong that morning?

turns.speaker: HARTLEY
turns.text: I didn't ask if you wanted milk.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: No.  A little sugar though.

turns.speaker: HARTLEY
turns.text: We've only got honey.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'll...take it straight.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: He thought it was cute when I called him Frankenstein.  It wasn't.  I feel like his monster.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Isn't it a lovely day?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: What happened to summer?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Summer's over.  It's fall.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: And winter?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, winter's far behind us now.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: How was it?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We had a terrible winter last year, didn't we, Sam?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So do you like your new room?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: It's interesting.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Your Dad spent all his spare time in here.  He wanted to make it absolutely perfect.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: I feel like a princess.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Is this mine?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes.  It's a present.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: From you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.  From Mr. Stephens.  That was him on the phone just now.  He was calling to see how you were.

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: Who's Mr. Stephens?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maybe we shouldn't be talking about this just now, with you barely home. Aren't you hungry, honey?  Want me to fix you something?

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: No.  What's this lawyer business?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nicole!

turns.speaker: NICOLE
turns.text: It's the truth.
